answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some sample policies regarding sewer backups on private property.
This is a copy of the Sewer Backup Policy and Procedure from Elko, NV.
http://www.ci.elko.nv.us/commdev/sewer_backup_policy.htm
The City of Smyrna, GA offers up to $600.00 for the installation of a backwater valves in homes in at risk areas.
http://www.smyrnacity.com/index.aspx?page=108
The City of Midland, MI has similar information on their site.
http://www.midland-mi.org/government/departments/utilities/wwsewerbackups.htm
The policy below on backups is from Scottsdale, AZ.
http://www.scottsdaleaz.gov/Water/services/Sewer_Backups
The City of Muskego, WI offers a grant program for Private Property Sewer Backup.
http://v3.mmsd.com/AssetsClient/Documents/PrivatePropertyI&I/Muskego062211FinalCombined.pdf
This is a copy of the Town of Mooresville, NC’s Sewer Back-up Policy.
http://www.egovlink.com/public_documents300/mooresville/published_documents/Utilities/Sewer_Back-Up_Policy.pdf
The Michigan Municipal League created a checklist for city managers on the best ways to prevent sewer backups.
http://www.mml.org/insurance/shared/pdf/risk_solutions/preventing_sewer_backups.pdf
I have also included a similar case study from City of Rochester, MN.
http://www.rochestermn.gov/departments/publicworks/hottopics/SanitaryIIStudy/20111006_Rochester_PrivateSectorI&I.pdf
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

answers.author: William Gilmore
answers.text:
Bobby
Some suggestions for you.  Most utility organizations will send you their rules and regulations or ordinances that define what is required.  However, as a former utility director, the best approach to addressing your questions are these:
a) cleanouts are best used in most communities as a preventive maintenance approach to keeping a sewer lateral clear if they get plugged.  It's also an an avenue to send a camera down to assess what a blockage may entail. 
b) In new developments, this should be a requirement.  In older areas, offering a grant to install or subsidizing installation have been used to encourage this.  
c) responsibility for sewer laterals varies by community.  Generally, its suggested that from the curb to the main is the utility's problem, and from the curb to the home is the homeowners problem.  The utility can agree to repair a failure on a lateral and charge back the cost based on a set hourly rate per employee, parts and equipment used.  Or the homeowner can contract for the repair after the utility has located the problem.  This is good customer service. 
d) flapper valves installed on sewer laterals in the home just before it leaves the basement or crawl space, are easy to install by a plumber.  These are best used in areas where historically, backups occur.  
Finally, a comprehensive set of rules and regulations that a city ordinance adopts as the standard guide for all to use I have found to aid in consolidating the information into one document and not spread through an ordinance book.  
Good luck,
Bill Gilmore

Plainsboro, NJ  08536

author: Bobby Jacobs
text: Do you have a policy or procedure (SOP) on how you handle sewer back-ups on private property (residential or commercial)? What part of the service line do you maintain (from the property line to the main / home-business to the main)? Do you require property line cleanouts to be installed?
title: Sewer Back-ups on Private Property
